Package Description
chapter_1_The_Basics
The first chapter of the book [COMPLETED]

The recipes in this chapter describe the basic syntax for lambda expressions, method references, and functional interfaces, as well the new support for static and default methods in interfaces
Recipe_1_1_Lambda_Expression
Recipe_1_2_Method_References

chapter_10_Java_9_Additions  
chapter_2_The_java_util_function_Package
The second chapter of the book [COMPLETED]

Lambda expressions and method references are always assigned to functional interfaces, which provide information about the SAM being implemented
The java.util.function package contains only functional interfaces that are reused in the rest of the library
Recipe_2_1_Consumers - take a generic argument and return nothing
Recipe_2_2_Suppliers - don't take any argument and return a value
Recipe_2_3_Predicates - take an argument and return a value
Recipe_2_4_Functions - take an argument and return a value

For each of the basic interfaces, there are different related ones
For eq, for Consumer we have variations for primitive types (IntConsumer, LongConsumer, etc) and a variation that takes two arguments and returns void (BiConsumer)
chapter_3_Streams
The third chapter of the book

A stream is a sequence of elements that does not save the elements or modify the original source
Functional programming in Java: generate a stream from some source of data, pass the elements through a series of intermediate operations (pipeline), and complete the process with a terminal expression
Streams can only be used once - after a stream has passed through zero or more intermediate operations and reached a terminal operation, it is finished and you need to make a new stream to process the values again
Streams are also lazy - a stream will only process as much data as it is necessary to reach the termianl condition
Recipe_3_1_Creating_Streams
Recipe_3_2_Boxed_Streams
Recipe_3_3_Reduction_Operations_Using_Reduce
Recipe_3_4_Check_Sorting_using_Reduce

Recipe_3_11_Stream_flatMap_Versus_map

Recipe_3_13_Lazy_Streams

chapter_6_The_Optional_Type
The sixth chapter of the book

The goal of Optional is not to remove NullPointerException but to communicate to the user when a returned v alue may legitimately be null

Methods in the Stream API that return an Option if there are no elements in the stream: reduce, min, max, findFirst, findAny
Recipe_6_1_Creating_An_Optional
Recipe_6_2_Retrieving_Values_from_an_Optional
